it.unimi.di.law.bubing.frontier

Class Frontier

  • java.lang.Object
    • it.unimi.di.law.bubing.frontier.Frontier
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    AbstractSieve.NewFlowReceiver<ByteArrayList>, it.unimi.dsi.jai4j.JobListener<BubingJob>

    public class Frontier
extends Object
implements it.unimi.dsi.jai4j.JobListener<BubingJob>, AbstractSieve.NewFlowReceiver<ByteArrayList>
    The BUbiNG frontier: a class structure that encompasses most of the logic behind the way BUbiNG fetches URLs. To understand how this class works, we invite the reader to consult the documentation of VisitState first.

    Every BUbiNG agent contains an instance of this class, which is responsible for starting and orchestrating the mutual interaction of many different elements:

    • the workbench (described below), that contains the VisitStates to be visited next;
    • the Distributor, that fills the workbench, possibly virtualizing part of it through a WorkbenchVirtualizer;
    • the TodoThread and the DoneThread, that move around VisitStates during the crawl;
    • a number of worker threads doing useful work, like DNSThread, FetchingThread and ParsingThread.

    How the frontier handles URLs

    URLs in BUbiNG belong to one of four states:

    • unknown: we have never seen the URL as yet;
    • waiting (to be filtered): we have seen the URL and we have enqueued it in the sieve, but the URL is waiting to be flushed (i.e., to be poured from the sieve to the readyURLs queue, which happens only the first time for every given URL);
    • ready: the URL has come out of the sieve, so it will be visited at some point in the future unless some limiting parameters (e.g., RuntimeConfiguration.maxUrlsPerSchemeAuthority) forbid it;
    • visited: the URL became ready and was somehow handled (e.g., fetched and possibly stored).

    Note that waiting URLs that happen to be ready or visited will never come out of the sieve: it is the logic of the sieve itself that inhibits the same object to be emitted twice.

    All ready URLs are initially stored in a ByteArrayDiskQueue called readyURLs, from which they are moved to the FIFO queue of their VisitState by the Distributor. Inside a VisitState, we only store a byte-array represention of the path+query of ready URLs. Some of them may be stored outside of the visit state, through virtualization. Keeping path+queries in byte-array form in all components reduces enormously object creation, and provides a simple form of compression by prefix omission.

    The lifecycle of a URL

    URLs are enqueued to the frontier either because they are part of the visit seed, or because a ParsingThread has found them, or because they have been submitted using JAI4J (this includes both manual submission and URLs sent by other agents). The method enqueue(ByteArrayList) will first check whether we have stored already too many URLs for the URL scheme+authority, in which case the URL is discarded; then, it will check whether the URL already appears in the URL cache (also in this case, the URL is discarded); finally it will check whether there is another agent responsible for the URL, and in this case the URL will be sent to the appropriate agent using the JAI4J infrastructure. If all checks have passed, the URL will be put in the sieve.

    The URL might never be dequeued from the sieve (because we have seen it already), but if it is, it will become ready by going through the append(long, ByteArrayList) method, which will again check that we do not have too many URLs for the URL authority, and then will enqueue the URL to the disk queue of ready URLs.

    Note that we expect that the vast majority of URLs will be of the first kind. This is very important, as there is much less contention on visit state locks than on the frontier lock.

      • requiredFrontSize

        public final AtomicLong requiredFrontSize
        The current estimation for the size of the front in IP addresses. It is adaptively increased when a FetchingThread has to wait to retrieve a VisitState from the todo queue. It is never more than half the number of path+queries that the workbench can hold.

      • enqueue

        public void enqueue(ByteArrayList url)
             throws IOException,
                    InterruptedException
        Enqueues a URL to the the BUbiNG crawl.

        Before enqueueing the URL to the sieve we perform a number of checks:

        • if there are too many URLs for the URL scheme+authority, we discard the URL;
        • if the URL appears in the URL cache, we discard it; otherwise, we add it to the cache;
        • if another agent is responsible for the URL, we submit it to the agent.

        The difference between this method and enqueueLocal(ByteArrayList) is that the latter does not check whether the argument is local.

        Parameters:
        url - a BUbiNG URL to be enqueued to the BUbiNG crawl.
        Throws:
        InterruptedException - from AbstractSieve.enqueue(Object, Object).
        IOException

      • workbenchIsFull

        public boolean workbenchIsFull()
        Returns whether the workbench is full.
        Returns:
        whether the workbench is full.

      • enqueueLocal

        public void enqueueLocal(ByteArrayList url)
                  throws IOException,
                         InterruptedException
        Enqueues a local URL represented by a byte array to the crawl of this agent.

        Before enqueueing the URL to the sieve we perform a number of checks:

        • if there are too many URLs for the URL scheme+authority, we discard the URL;
        • if the URL appears in the URL cache, we discard it; otherwise, we add it to the cache.

        The difference between this method and enqueue(ByteArrayList) is that the latter checks whether the argument is local.

        Parameters:
        url - a BUbiNG URL to be enqueued to the BUbiNG crawl, in byte-array representation.
        Throws:
        InterruptedException - from AbstractSieve.enqueue(Object, Object).
        IOException

      • updateRequestedFrontSize

        public void updateRequestedFrontSize()
        Update, if necessary, the requiredFrontSize. The current front size is the number of visit states present in the workbench and in the todo queue. If this quantity is larged than the currently-required front size, the latter is increase by FRONT_INCREASE, although it will never be set to a value larger than half of the workbench (two queries per visit state).
